description.para: Defines the allocator type of a data structure.
Sets the capacity of a data structure at compile-time.
This implies that a data structure is bounded and fixed-sized.
Configures a data structure as fixed-sized.

The internal nodes are stored inside an array and they are addressed by array indexing. This limits the possible size of the queue to the number of elements that can be addressed by the index type (usually 2**16-2), but on platforms that lack double-width compare-and-exchange instructions, this is the best way to achieve lock-freedom. This implies that a data structure is bounded.

The queue class provides a multi-writer/multi-reader queue, pushing and popping is lock-free, construction/destruction has to be synchronized. It uses a freelist for memory management, freed nodes are pushed to the freelist and not returned to the OS before the queue is destroyed.

listitem.para: boost::lockfree::fixed_sized, defaults to boost::lockfree::fixed_sized<false> Can be used to completely disable dynamic memory allocations during push in order to ensure lockfree behavior. If the data structure is configured as fixed-sized, the internal nodes are stored inside an array and they are addressed by array indexing. This limits the possible size of the queue to the number of elements that can be addressed by the index type (usually 2**16-2), but on platforms that lack double-width compare-and-exchange instructions, this is the best way to achieve lock-freedom.
boost::lockfree::capacity, optional If this template argument is passed to the options, the size of the queue is set at compile-time. This option implies fixed_sized<true>
boost::lockfree::allocator, defaults to boost::lockfree::allocator<std::allocator<void>> Specifies the allocator that is used for the internal freelist
T must have a copy constructor
T must have a trivial assignment operator
T must have a trivial destructor

warning.para: It only checks, if the queue head and tail nodes and the freelist can be modified in a lock-free manner. On most platforms, the whole implementation is lock-free, if this is true. Using c++0x-style atomics, there is no possibility to provide a completely accurate implementation, because one would need to test every internal node, which is impossible if further nodes will be allocated from the operating system.

returns.para: true, if implementation is lock-free.

description.para: Destroys queue, free all nodes from freelist.
Check if the queue is empty

note.para: The result is only accurate, if no other thread modifies the queue. Therefore it is rarely practical to use this value in program logic.

returns.para: true, if the queue is empty, false otherwise

description.para: Pushes object t to the queue.

note.para: Thread-safe. If internal memory pool is exhausted and the memory pool is not fixed-sized, a new node will be allocated from the OS. This may not be lock-free.

postconditions.para: object will be pushed to the queue, if internal node can be allocated

returns.para: true, if the push operation is successful.

description.para: Pushes object t to the queue.

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking. If internal memory pool is exhausted, operation will fail

postconditions.para: object will be pushed to the queue, if internal node can be allocated

returns.para: true, if the push operation is successful.

description.para: Pushes object t to the queue.

note.para: Not Thread-safe. If internal memory pool is exhausted and the memory pool is not fixed-sized, a new node will be allocated from the OS. This may not be lock-free.

postconditions.para: object will be pushed to the queue, if internal node can be allocated

returns.para: true, if the push operation is successful.

description.para: Pops object from queue.

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking

postconditions.para: if pop operation is successful, object will be copied to ret.

returns.para: true, if the pop operation is successful, false if queue was empty.

description.para: Pops object from queue.

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking

requires.para: type U must be constructible by T and copyable, or T must be convertible to U

postconditions.para: if pop operation is successful, object will be copied to ret.

returns.para: true, if the pop operation is successful, false if queue was empty.

description.para: Pops object from queue.

note.para: Not thread-safe, but non-blocking

postconditions.para: if pop operation is successful, object will be copied to ret.

returns.para: true, if the pop operation is successful, false if queue was empty.

description.para: Pops object from queue.

note.para: Not thread-safe, but non-blocking

requires.para: type U must be constructible by T and copyable, or T must be convertible to U

postconditions.para: if pop operation is successful, object will be copied to ret.

returns.para: true, if the pop operation is successful, false if queue was empty.

description.para: consumes one element via a functor
pops one element from the queue and applies the functor on this object

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking, if functor is thread-safe and non-blocking

returns.para: true, if one element was consumed

pops one element from the queue and applies the functor on this object

description.para: consumes all elements via a functor
sequentially pops all elements from the queue and applies the functor on each object

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking, if functor is thread-safe and non-blocking

returns.para: number of elements that are consumed

description.para: consumes all elements via a functor
sequentially pops all elements from the queue and applies the functor on each object

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking, if functor is thread-safe and non-blocking

returns.para: number of elements that are consumed

description.para: The spsc_queue class provides a single-writer/single-reader fifo queue, pushing and popping is wait-free.

listitem.para: boost::lockfree::capacity<>, optional If this template argument is passed to the options, the size of the ringbuffer is set at compile-time.

boost::lockfree::allocator<>, defaults to boost::lockfree::allocator<std::allocator<T>> Specifies the allocator that is used to allocate the ringbuffer. This option is only valid, if the ringbuffer is configured to be sized at run-time
T must have a default constructor

description.para: Constructs a spsc_queue

requires.para: spsc_queue must be configured to be sized at compile-time

description.para: Constructs a spsc_queue with a custom allocator

note.para: This is just for API compatibility: an allocator isn't actually needed

requires.para: spsc_queue must be configured to be sized at compile-time

description.para: Constructs a spsc_queue with a custom allocator

note.para: This is just for API compatibility: an allocator isn't actually needed

requires.para: spsc_queue must be configured to be sized at compile-time

description.para: Constructs a spsc_queue for element_count elements

requires.para: spsc_queue must be configured to be sized at run-time

description.para: Constructs a spsc_queue for element_count elements with a custom allocator

requires.para: spsc_queue must be configured to be sized at run-time

description.para: Constructs a spsc_queue for element_count elements with a custom allocator

requires.para: spsc_queue must be configured to be sized at run-time

description.para: Pushes object t to the ringbuffer.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to push data to the spsc_queue

postconditions.para: object will be pushed to the spsc_queue, unless it is full.

returns.para: true, if the push operation is successful.

description.para: Pops one object from ringbuffer.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to pop data to the spsc_queue

postconditions.para: if ringbuffer is not empty, object will be discarded.

returns.para: true, if the pop operation is successful, false if ringbuffer was empty.

description.para: Pops one object from ringbuffer.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to pop data to the spsc_queue

postconditions.para: if ringbuffer is not empty, object will be copied to ret.

returns.para: true, if the pop operation is successful, false if ringbuffer was empty.

description.para: Pushes as many objects from the array t as there is space.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to push data to the spsc_queue

returns.para: number of pushed items

description.para: Pushes as many objects from the array t as there is space available.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to push data to the spsc_queue

returns.para: number of pushed items

description.para: Pushes as many objects from the range [begin, end) as there is space .

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to push data to the spsc_queue

returns.para: iterator to the first element, which has not been pushed

description.para: Pops a maximum of size objects from ringbuffer.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to pop data to the spsc_queue

returns.para: number of popped items

description.para: Pops a maximum of size objects from spsc_queue.

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to pop data to the spsc_queue

returns.para: number of popped items

description.para: Pops objects to the output iterator it

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only one thread is allowed to pop data to the spsc_queue

returns.para: number of popped items

pops one element from the queue and applies the functor on this object

note.para: Thread-safe and non-blocking, if functor is thread-safe and non-blocking

returns.para: true, if one element was consumed

description.para: get number of elements that are available for read

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free, should only be called from the consumer thread

returns.para: number of available elements that can be popped from the spsc_queue

description.para: get write space to write elements

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free, should only be called from the producer thread

returns.para: number of elements that can be pushed to the spsc_queue

description.para: get reference to element in the front of the queue
Availability of front element can be checked using read_available().

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only a consuming thread is allowed to check front element
read_available() > 0. If ringbuffer is empty, it's undefined behaviour to invoke this method.

returns.para: reference to the first element in the queue

description.para: get reference to element in the front of the queue
Availability of front element can be checked using read_available().

note.para: Thread-safe and wait-free

requires.para: only a consuming thread is allowed to check front element
read_available() > 0. If ringbuffer is empty, it's undefined behaviour to invoke this method.

returns.para: reference to the first element in the queue

description.para: reset the ringbuffer

note.para: Not thread-safe

description.para: The stack class provides a multi-writer/multi-reader stack, pushing and popping is lock-free, construction/destruction has to be synchronized. It uses a freelist for memory management, freed nodes are pushed to the freelist and not returned to the OS before the stack is destroyed.

listitem.para: boost::lockfree::fixed_sized<>, defaults to boost::lockfree::fixed_sized<false> Can be used to completely disable dynamic memory allocations during push in order to ensure lockfree behavior. If the data structure is configured as fixed-sized, the internal nodes are stored inside an array and they are addressed by array indexing. This limits the possible size of the stack to the number of elements that can be addressed by the index type (usually 2**16-2), but on platforms that lack double-width compare-and-exchange instructions, this is the best way to achieve lock-freedom.
boost::lockfree::capacity<>, optional If this template argument is passed to the options, the size of the stack is set at compile-time. It this option implies fixed_sized<true>
boost::lockfree::allocator<>, defaults to boost::lockfree::allocator<std::allocator<void>> Specifies the allocator that is used for the internal freelist
T must have a copy constructor

parameter.paramtype: (mpl::if_c< has_capacity, mpl::bool_< capacity - 1< boost::integer_traits< boost::uint16_t >::const_max >, mpl::true_ >::type::value)

warning.para: It only checks, if the top stack node and the freelist can be modified in a lock-free manner. On most platforms, the whole implementation is lock-free, if this is true. Using c++0x-style atomics, there is no possibility to provide a completely accurate implementation, because one would need to test every internal node, which is impossible if further nodes will be allocated from the operating system.

returns.para: true, if implementation is lock-free.

note.para: It only guarantees that at some point during the execution of the function the stack has been empty. It is rarely practical to use this value in program logic, because the stack can be modified by other threads.

returns.para: true, if stack is empty.
